name: HuniePop
description: HuniePop is a unique sim experience for PC, Mac and Linux. It's a gameplay first approach that's part dating sim, part puzzle game, with light RPG elements, a visual novel style of presentation, an abrasive western writing style and plenty of "plot".
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP+ Processor: 1.2 GHz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: DirectX® 9 Compatible Graphics Card DirectX: Version 9.0a Storage: 1 GB available space

reviews.review_text: Fun game Pros: -The puzzles are the reasons to get the game  Cons: -having to explain to my roommate why implaying this game -having to exxplain to my grilfriend why implaying this game and why did i even buy it. -trying to convince people i only got it for the puzzles

What I've learned from this game:  - Dating and having sex does not become any easier with experience. In fact, it becomes much more difficult. - Chicks dig pretenders. Do NOT try to be yourself. Trust me, it's not gonna work. - It's completely OK to ask questions about weight and bra size. Girls expect you to do so. - There is little to no reason to ever have anything to do with someone you've already banged. Move on.  HuniePop is pretty much your regular light dating sim. You ask girls generic questions, they in return quiz you to find out if you've paid any attention at all and in the end, if done correctly, you've humped every girl in town. For some reason though it feels more fun than dating sims usually. I'm still trying to determine if it actually is more fun or am I just being fooled to think so.  If you've played any dating sim before, especially any western-made, you've seen most of this game already. First you're introduced with your mission to get down with every girl you meet. Sometimes it's because you're trying to win a bet, sometimes you're doing it just for the hell of it, sometimes you're getting revenge, and so on, and so on. This time the reason is a magic fairy who comes to your aid because you're a pathetic mess and need to get some poon-tang ASAP. Then you run rampant around the town meeting girls and memorizing trivia you learn from them. Wooing the girls can be made easier by handing them various obtainable gifts.  What's different in this game is dating. Instead of putting anything you've learned in actual use, you're playing a round of Bejeweled... Candy Crush... You know, that puzzle game where there's a board full of bricks of different colors and you're supposed to swap bricks to create lines of three or more of same color. You need to get certain amount of points and you have 20 turns to do so. If you succeed, date is successful and your prey likes you a little bit more. However, every time you win a date game, next date becomes more difficult with higher target score. You can improve your in-game skills to get point multipliers, but at some point you're likely to find yourself in a situation where every move has to be magnificent. There's no time limit though, and sooner or later you're gonna understand why.  Once you've managed to bend your target under your will, it's time to move to your bedroom. Again you're facing your nemesis, the bling-bling puzzle game, but this time it's slightly different. You have unlimited moves, but your score keeps running down to zero. In order to reach your target you need to score faster than your points decrease. During this your conquest stands next to you in her underwear moaning. It's rather peculiar portrayal of intercourse, I must say. It makes you feel like you're rolling all over the place like a tornado, trying to twist and tweak everything you can, as fast as you can. If you can conjure a hysteric state of mind at will, it will be extremely helpful.  The game is put together very well. Graphics are pretty, background music can run hours without becoming annoying and voice acting is a lot better than you would expect, although sometimes it's difficult to believe that every girl has their own voice actress. Girls have extremely different, yet quite stereotypical personalities. Dialogue varies from hilarious to awkward to annoying, so a lot, but thanks to voice acting you don't want to skip any of it (unless you really hate the girl in question).  There are some minor nuisances. Once you've done the deed with a girl, there isn't any reason to interact with her again. There are some minor details like costumes and hairstyles you can always try to unlock but nothing that affects gameplay and nothing that matters at all in any way if you're not gonna see that girl anymore, and again, why would you? Item inventory has less space than there are items to obtain. For some reason this becomes quite annoying, especially because there is absolutely no reason to limit the size of inventory. Also, there are Steam cards but no achievements. Personally I would've picked achievements over trading cards, but that's just me.  I still don't know for sure whether HuniePop really is fun or just masked as fun. I'm playing it hours at a time, but I'm not exactly sure why. It doesn't really bring anything new to the table. It doesn't offer anything I haven't yet seen. If you're familiar with dating sims this one is going to feel familiar right off the bat. I recommend this game, but ONLY if you like the genre or want to find out what dating sims are. Even though it's very generic, it's still very well made and an excellent example of a dating sim. If you've tried dating sims before and haven't liked them, this one is not gonna change that opinion.

Fairly run-of-the-mill in terms of adult content, nothing you wouldn't see on Rule 34 or something similar. The puzzle game itself is surprisingly addicting, though, and the characters are pretty enjoyable. My favorite character overall is probably Aiko, but Kyu is far and away the funniest of the bunch. If someone made a mod where she was voiced by John DeLancey (get it, Q, Kyu?), I think I'd die laughing.  The game revels in how politically incorrect it is. Every woman you meet is pretty much one or another stereotype (i.e. the good girl, the mega-♥♥♥♥♥, the catgirl, etc.), as Kyu herself is often quick to point out. Most of the women play their parts to such a straight degree that it's hard not to laugh, but Kyu's 'no fourth wall' conversations turn the whole thing into pure gold ('Come on, seduce me with your sexy puzzle skills!').  It isn't really possible to 'lose' at HuniePop, per se, but each successive puzzle gets progressively higher point requirements to clear it, and if you don't make the most out of each portion of the day (particularly the night portion), you can quickly find yourself falling behind the curve; even easy mode will start to give you trouble going into your second week. Thankfully, you only  have  to pass the first four dates with each girl to make progress, after which you're free to fail as often as you like.  Overall, it's a decent way to pass the afternoon. You're not gonna find the meaning of life in this game, but you will be entertained.

HuniePop, a dating simulator where you impress the girl using your match-three, Bejeweled or Candy Crush skills. Match accordingly to the girl's most preferred traits and try to avoid her least preferred traits whenever possible. Make sure not to match the broken hearts!  Sounds: The voice acting is all right.  Music/Soundtrack: The music gets sort of repetitive over time.  Addictiveness: It's pretty addictive if you are into match-three, Bejeweled or Candy Crush type of games and are into weird anime stuff.  User Interface: I'd say the user interface is pretty good for a dating simulator game like this. However, I had to run the game  Windowed  as opposed to my preferred  Full-Screen No Border  as for some reason the visuals in both left and right sides get messed up if I happen to force it to run full-screen no border.  Story: It's about you dating more and more girls through the power of match-three and trying your best to not let them know you're cheating on them.  Gameplay: You just play the game as how you would play a match-three game, Bejeweled or Candy Crush, except it's sort of mixed with some Visual Novel gameplay. However, you are given  date gifts  and  traits  that are meant to help you out during the match-three gameplay.  Characters: The characters in HuniePop are somewhat an exaggerated version of realistic personalities. You have the cute, pure and short girl everyone likes. There's also the ♥♥♥♥♥y, hot and ♥♥♥♥♥♥-bag girl every guy likes. Then there's you, the perverted weeaboo who decided that you don't have the courage to ask a guy/girl out on a date in real life and decided to play this game.  Enjoyment: ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)  At the time of posting this review, it is 26th of June 2015 and I have 10 hours played with a 66% progression on my save game. I will edit accordingly as I read feedback, put more time and progress further into the game.

I have to admit, I purchased this because I'd seen the Let's Play videos of ths game and because the premise was just so ridiculous that you couldn't help but have your curiousity piqued. There are some reviews/coverage out there that paints this game as being an insult to women, but I didn't entirely see this. I suppose that to a point I could see where some are coming from with that, but any sexism was definitely not intended.   Your enjoyment of this game will ultimately boil down to how much you like games like Bejeweled since that's really the main thrust of the game (no pun intended). The dating sim aspects are somewhat weak and mostly there to string together the various game levels for each girl and give you power ups. The story is probably the weakest part of the game and probably why the charges of sexism are even being levied, since there really isn't a lot to these women other than their datability. While yes, this is an aspect of datings sims to a degree, the good dating sims give you a chance to become at least slightly emotionally invested in the characters. I didn't really get that feeling with this game's characters- not even the person we're supposed to be portraying.   Some of this I can handwave away by this being a 'first game' that was funded via Kickstarter. The learning process is always a rough one and for this to be the developer's first official game and sorta dating sim (that I'm aware of) it's a pretty darn good one since there are no visible glitches or errors that interrupt gameplay. I'm aware that there wll be a second game and I hope that the developer brings in more character development since that was something that was sorely missing with this game. The dating sim aspect was no risk and while I didn't entirely mind that, I did want to see more interaction with the characters and more development. This game had a lot of potential and while it lives up to that on the matching game end, it was sorely lacking on the dating sim angle. I think that more character development, the ability to have some slight risk (like being caught with another girl means that you can't date one or both girls for a set period of time), and the ability to choose a Final Girl would have improved this greatly and would be great to have in the sequel.   Ultimately I'd recommend this, but not to anyone looking for a more involved dating sim or one with any true storyline.

To be perfectly honest, this is the first game I've ever purchased on Steam; account authentication requires you to buy $5 worth of items to chat, and the deluxe edition was on sale for $5.09 during the Thanksgiving sale, so it worked out.  Sure, a lot of my friends may refer to this game as a 'DON'T DO IT', or a 'WHY!?!?', but the reason I logged 40+ hours into this game isn't really the girls at all- it's the core gameplay. The puzzles.  I never thought I'd get into Match-3 titles, especially seeing how my mom adores Candy Crush. I even tried a few of her levels, and it... wasn't satisfying. Popcap's original Bejeweled didn't cut it either, since the gameplay felt too ordinary and unadventurous. Huniepop teeters on an interesting trek since the developers decided to implement their own take on the Match-3 system, and rather than cut boosters entirely, they're gained through gameplay by earning 'Sentiment' points by matching specific sets of tokens, rather than buying the boosters before playing. A huge step up from mobile Match-3's.  If you like Match-3 games, give this a shot. There may be some uncomfortable moments here and there, but from what can be observed, Huniepop is (imo) the best Match-3 in recent memory. Consider purchasing it during a steam sale, since the price for the standard version can go down to 3 dollars.

Lets see where to begin.... Well lets start with the obvious, puzzles and porn, two things that never in a million years would I have thought that they could be mixed together but this dev did it, and quite successfully too. Huniepop delivers on what they advertised on steam, and along with the devs generously providing the means to get the uncensored version of the game, I would say it is worth the money and time.  This game does have a few weaknesses though, especially for those whom have never played a puzzle game before, or don't find puzzles to be very compelling. (like me).  The game's tutorial is rather light on teaching a new player on how to effectively match the pieces, to say nothing of teaching how to pull off a 'multiple combo' in which a player can clear a good portion of the board at once, for me its still seems like random luck despite playing it for 12 hours. A tutorial that details that aspect of getting the most out of your moves would be welcomed. Easy mode could also be more 'easy', don't underestimate my utter lack of skill when it comes to puzzles.  Another issue is the lack of interaction choices with the various women in the game, its the same three questions, (And same greetings) despite the fact you have asked (Or met) them before. They certainly do not change based on their relationship with the player either. And while yes this game is  not  meant to be a serious dating sim,(More on this later) a small amount of effort put here by the devs would be welcome.  Now as for the 'plot'. I will say right now that I  have not completed the game, nor have I unlocked all the characters , so I could very well be missing something very big. That being said what I have seen so far passes off as bare minimal at best, and that  surprisingly is a good thing , since this game seems more like a  spoof  on the dating sim genre and plays on some of the various tropes, and sterotypes quite well, and seems to poke fun at itself too.  Those of you looking for a more serious dating sim would do well too look elsewhere.  Now for what everyone has been waiting for.... the 'pictures' are done very well, (could stand to have more for each character though, but thats just my personal gripe.) The voice actresses are also surprisingly good as well.  Well I think that everything that needs to be said about this game, its good for what it does, its  not  a bad game by any means but at least for  me , the one who sucks at puzzles, I don't know if the promise of new characters, more nude pictures, and possible plot is enough to persuade me to continue 'grinding' through increasingly difficult puzzles for a set of three to four pics, even if they are well done. Though I am sure I will attempt to progress from time to time.

The best dating simulator I have ever played, and i've tried them all.   Graphics: 5/5, the gui is amazing compared to other dating sims, the girls even have voice actors and their mouths move! That was mind blowing for me.   Story: 4/5, it's the usual dating sim plotline - get the girls in bed, but i'll add that you can get ALL of them in bed, which is amazing.   Characters: 5/5, all unique, diverse, and they actually have personalities, they're not just the regular schoolgirl with little quirks.   You can even be a girl, which is a pretty huge step considering most dating sims feature a male protagonist. On top of everything else, the main 'game' of the game (ie dating minigame) is actually quite hard. It takes planning, skill, and technique. You can fail a date multiple times, or get lucky, or use date items to help you out.   This game is a parody of all dating sims, and ends up the best one of all.   9/10 - only complaint is a minor one: i'd like to be able to have a name, or a face to my character.

So, my history with hentai-date-sim games goes back to Newgrounds and the likes of 'Simgirl' and 'Ganguro Girl'. In regards to the elements that are common between all the games in that particular genre, HuniePop is neither better nor worse than all the others that have come before it; if the formula isn't broken, don't fix it, just make it shinier and with higher production values.  Perhaps the strangest thing about HuniePop is that once you get past the, 'Yay! Boobies!' facet of things, you will probably discover that the actual game portion of the game is pretty great. While essentially a standard 'match 3' type of mini-game, there is a surprising amount of strategy to be found when you start to factor in the various 'date gifts' and how they interact with the simple nature of the system.  For anyone that is playing this game just because of the ecchi element, I'm reasonably certain there are a thousand more efficient ways of getting your porn fix than by playing a casual puzzle game. If you initially came (pun intended) for the jiggly-bits, then stick around and give the game the scrutiny it deserves by trying Alpha Mode; you'll learn to get a lot better at matching tiles really quick, or get laughed at by hot anime girls... Either way is a win in my opinion.

HuniePop is one part dating sim and one part match-three puzzle game. What makes the game genius is how each of these two systems intertwine. Talk to girls to get Hunie, which you can use to buy upgrades for your puzzle skills. Play puzzles to earn Munie to buy the girls gifts/food/alcohol. The different colored orbs during the puzzles all correspond to different personality traits, which each girl will respond differently to. Buying girls especially good gifts will unlock special 'date gifts', which vary widely in effect, that you can equip and use once per puzzle.   Basically, HuniePop is every dating sim trope refined to a tee, and then perfectly intertwined with a deeper version of Candy Crush. No action feels pointless, there are plenty of secrets to find, and by the time things could potential feel like a grind, you've already gotten your money's worth.   Among the best dating sims I've played. A must-play for any fan of the genre.

God, where to start?  First, the gameplay. It's solid. It plays much like Bejeweled, but there is a larger amount of freedom in preparing for dates and moving tokens on the playable board, allowing for more strategic gameplay rather than purely relying on how good a board you start with. Dates will get steadily harder but it does not have any gimmicks introduced, allowing a fairer difficulty curve. Not to say that the later dates get near impossible without the right loadout. All in all, decent gameplay.  The characters themselves are rather one-dimensional however, and the lack of a storyline for any of the characters outside of 'bang every broad in a 5-mile radius' makes it fall rather flat. Don't expect to be feeling very much outside of euphoria from finally beating the final Bejeweled Blitz game (more affectionately known as SANIC BEJEWELED). If you are looking for more emotional and convincing characters, I would suggest looking for Visual Novels instead (Nekopara is a personal favourite of mine). However, the character dialogue is rather hilarious at times, and is the sort of B-movie slop that you will simply get hooked on.  Dating Sim gameplay is rather simple. Give presents, ask and answer questions, and stuff your waifu with food and drink. This is the only way of getting one of the currencies in the game called Hunie, neede for upgrading Traits to make the Bejeweled sections easier. To get Munie you need to sharpen up you match-3 skills.  HOWEVER, there is one other thing.  THE SOUNDTRACK IS AMAZING. I would HIGHLY suggest getting the Digital Soundtrack if you intend on buying this game. The tunes are catchy, yet also soothing. You can see for yourself how good the music is if you get the game yourself.  All in all, I can highly recommend this game. First, you come for the waifus. Second, you stay for the surprisingly good gameplay complexity. Lastly, you get earworms.  BUY IT.

You’ll find there’s nothing more rewarding then taking a girl back to your place to play Candy Crush. Joke aside the bedroom mini-game is certainly not a carbon copy of the date puzzles. The best way to describe Huniepop is it's pretty much drugs, once you get a taste of it you can never get enough. This game will consume the soul of anyone who buys it. Don't believe me, my cousin played this game 12 hours straight without food or water and whenever I tried to get him off of it he nearly went berserk. It wasn't until I bought it that I understood why he loved it so much.  The premise of the game is pretty straightforward and simple, you're a huge loser who can't even hold a conversation with a girl but then a love fairy named Kyu comes into your life and helps you overcome your jirttery and nervous personality so you can become a hit with the ladies. As you talk to girls you increase your skills and successfully transform into an egotistical womanizer.  I kind of wish there was an actual story with an ending and I think it would've been funny to see what would've happened if one of the girls caught you cheating but that doesn't make the game any less fun.  The voice acting is AWESOME! The actresses should be given awards because their performance was superb. Each girl had a different personality that made you fall in love with them and some that you could personally relate to.  As for the dating candy crush mini game, I have to say I never saw this coming. In this game you have to use each different token of affection according to what each girl likes. It's really cool especially coming from someone who sucks at candy crush.  The soundtrack is beautiful. It was really well done and it worked with each setting. My personal favorites are the Lusties Nightclub and the Farmers Market.  As for the secret characters, I didn't mind Celeste one but, we already have a love fairy follwing us around so having an alien show up didn't really surprise me. Now Momo, I want nothing to do with her. She creeps me out and she is the only character of the cast I dislike. My advice go for celeste and ignore Momo, the secret characters aren't mandatory.  As for the negatives, there are only few but there are some. I notice that whenever you move your mouse, the screen moves slightly left and right when I feel like more can be put into that because honestly what was the point of including it if it onlys moves left and right only slightly. Also, I understand they want us to imagine the protagonist as ourselves. However, how can you have us choose whether to be male or female and not give us the chance to create our own character. There comes a point in every person’s life when they look at the situation they’re in and think to themselves, “what the hell am I doing?” This revelation can strike any time: during a class for a useless degree, a waning relationship, a drug deal with a co-worker. My moment of clarity, if you will, hit me when I needed it most, in the midst of a frantic dash for three-jewel matches as I worked to build a lazily-drawn, not-anime girl’s o-meter.  It brought me back to reality, back from that dark place in the back of my head where I go when I need to retreat from the world’s ugliness. This happened just as the screen faded and the poor voice actress’ bored moans grew in volume and doused in effects. I was rewarded with yet another CG image of a naked woman in an inhuman pose, covered in fluids.  Yes, I’m reviewing an adult game. A match-three, adult game. A Kickstarted, match-three, adult game. A Kickstarted, match-three, adult game that received over $50 grand.  I play it for the puzzles, mom, I swear!  Here’s the deal: your character is a perpetually virginal loser. You’re so sexually hopeless you incur the wrath of the love goddess, and she sends an almost-naked, fairy lady to turn dates with women into a video game, because that’s your only skill. You’re actually so terrible at life, the fairy girl sees your case as a special challenge and goes the extra mile to make sure you get laid, and often. The projection in HuniePop’s (really bad, but who’s surprised?) writing is so thick you can cut it with a disapproving grimace.  With your new gamified romance powers, you get to stalk a group of women with your magic radar phone, and ask them invasive questions out of the blue, because that’s totally how approaching women works. You can also go out on date, which takes you to HuniePop’s pretend gimmick (I mean, seriously, there’s porn): the “puzzle stuff,” as HuniePop’s Kickstarter pitch so eloquently puts it.  When Irony Attacks  So, here we are. HuniePop. A bland puzzle game that pretends to have depth, a dating sim you can’t lose that glorifies loserdom to an uncomfortable level and lame porn. Why bother? If you want anime porn, there’s plenty of visual novels or eroge or whatever out there featuring much less secondhand embarrassment. If you want a puzzle game, with gimmicks and depth, there’s like fifty better options out there. HuniePop is a lose-lose situation. It isn’t even worth much of a laugh, frankly. It’s just boring. Also, if you get it on Steam, it isn’t even porn anymore. HuniePop.  2/10 Would Play For The Puzzle Again

Well, I never really thought I'd ever play a game quite like this, Nor did I think I'd find it so fun. But, here I am, writing a review for the new game called 'HuniePop', a combination of every Hentai dating sim and Bejeweled style puzzles games. So, without further ado, let's give you the story.  Story: You are a guy/girl who is unlucky in love. However, one day, a Love Fairy named Kyu approaches you with the offer of a lifetime, the chance to teach you how to seduce girls. Now, armed with your trusty HunieBee, plenty of gifts and pick up lines, AND one hell of a libido, you are off to win the hearts of 8 lucky ladies, plus a few secret girls~  Pros: Now, let's just start off by saying that the premise of a dating sim mixed with Bejeweled is very interesting, and handled well here. It is quite challenging, even on easy mode, so don't exactly plan to breeze through this. The tutorial for the game is also good and gets you a full idea on how the mechanics work. It also has some very great voice work that will likely make you decide you actually WANT to hear the women talk (though it DOES leave the option to turn off their voices). Furthermore, the women are each unique and fun to watch (though some aren't AS likeable, you will qucikly find). The HunieBee menu is also pretty easy to go through, besides some minor difficulties (which I'll explain later). The artwork is really lovely, with some of it being cute while a large portion is nice and sexy. Also, for those who are more hardcore when it comes to games, worry not. Because this game also has an 'Alpha Mode' which you can get once you successfully seduce all the girls, including that 'final boss' whom I won't reveal. In this mode, all dates you go in will be in Hard Mode AND increase in difficulty with every date. And finally for what it arguably lacks in story it makes up for with a rather off the wall, inappropriate humor that manages to come off as surprisingly charming despite itself. From having your Love Fairy mention having a taste for chocolate (she's talking about a black woman) to one of the girls, Audrey, asking another girl if she 'hurt [her] ♥♥♥♥♥ feelings, the funny moments can be too many to count and honestly come off as hilarious, whether because it sounds surprisingly natural, or because it's much too corny to take seriously.  Cons: Now, while I did mention quite a few pros, a few of them could actually count as cons for other people. First of all, there's the fact that this game really has no real story or even character development, besides your guy/girl going from a shy, simple virgin to the town's biggest sleeparound. Oh yeah, did I mention that you sleep with every girl in the entire game and yet still go on dates with each one, INCLUDING a mother and her own college age daughter (granted, they're enstranged from one another, but still)? Because yeah, that's exactly what happens. And combine that with all the drug & alcohol references, inappropriate humor, some of the less likable characters (Audrey and her excessive swearing can feel quite grating when she isn't funny) and the mere fact that you end up collecting the panties of the girls you sleep with can easily make this a conservative's worst nightmare. Oh yeah, and if you aren't into the game's humor (which you can easily get a feel for early on), then trust me when I say it doesn't get any better. As a final, but minor note, I find that the HunieBee menu for the info on the different girls can be a bit of a pain to go through since you have to rely on the arrows to get you through it rather than tabs going to what you want to look at. Not big, but still annoying.  All in all, I was honestly happy with my experience playing this game, and NOT just because of the hentai elements. To put it simply, I managed to find that I actually enjoyed the puzzles and found winning the hearts of all the women to feel rewarding, expecially when I made them happy. While it can easily be argued that it stoops pretty low in terms of both the premise and humor, you may just find that to be a part of the charm. So if you can at least get a demo of it, try it out first and if you like it, go ahead and buy it. I honestly feel happy that I gave it a try.

All the fun of being a cad and a womaniser, plus match three puzzles!  So, now I'll be that guy who writes a serious review of a porn game. Because make no mistake -- that's what this is. The cutesy art style in the sample screenshots may deceive you, but as the game progresses, it becomes quite explicit. If you're not comfortable with that, stay away -- and probably don't buy this for your kids. It is, however, as wholesome as a porn game can get; there is no violence and no coercion, no 'bad ends' or gruesome situations. It's just purely consentual, happy encounters and positive outcomes.  In gameplay terms, it's simple and repetitive, but fairly fun. It's basically a match-three game with a rudimentary dating sim tacked on to the front, but with none of the (rather arbitrary and frustrating) mechanics dating sims often suffer under. There are no lose conditions in this game; you can fail at individual puzzle boards and botch sim interactions, but there's no way to lose the game entirely, nor is there any way to screw up your relationship with any of the girls such that you can't just try again tomorrow. Each of the girls (there are several) has her own likes and dislikes, and must be appropriately courted with gifts and flattered with question responses in order to unlock her outfits and hairstyles. Meanwhile, you can also ask them out on dates, which brings you to a match-three board. Completing the board increases that girl's affection for you, and brings you that much closer to the explicit scenes.  The actual sex scenes are, strangely enough, also match-three puzzles, but these are of the 'speed matching' variety, and are easily the most annoying thing in the game. The pleasure meter drains  so  rapidly that strategy becomes next to impossible; mainly, you have to grab and drag whatever you can as fast as you can, or you'll lose all the progress you've made. Still and all, it doesn't appear to be possible to fail at these -- in extremis, your meter will drain all the way back to zero and you have to start over again.  The game has, as the screenshots above demonstrate, a definite anime art style. It's fairly well executed, though entirely static -- there is no animation anywhere in the game. By default, the game is also censored, though the developer has made available a patch that removes the censors; be aware that the uncensored images are  very  explicit, so don't use the patch if you aren't comfortable with that.   The 'abrasive western writing style' certainly is quite abrasive. The dialogue consists of annoying internet memes, distrssingly on-the-nose faux-cool talk, and swearing. Lots of swearing. Call me old-fashioned -- or, not to put too fine a point to it, just plain  old  -- but I don't appreciate the girls in this game all cursing like sailors all the time. It's not just one or two 'edgy' characters, either; all of the girls are rather foul-mouthed. It's rather a shame; if a bit more work had been done on writing decent text rather than just internet in-jokes and foul language, it would have done wonders to improve the experience. There is, after all, quite a lot of dialogue.  There is voice acting. It is exactly as bad as you expect. Fortunately, there is a quite simple way to disable it, and you even have the option of replacing it with 'bloops' so the dialogue boxes aren't purely silent.  Overall, this game is worth your ten dollars if you like match three games and porn. If either of those things is not to your taste, then give it a miss.
